chapter.title: Accessing File Systems with FUSE

abstract.para: FUSE is the acronym for file system in userspace. This means you can configure and mount a file system as an unprivileged user. Normally, you have to be root for this task. FUSE alone is a kernel module. Combined with plug-ins, it allows you to extend FUSE to access almost all file systems like remote SSH connections, ISO images, and more.

sect1.title: Configuring FUSE
sect1.para: Before you can use FUSE, you have to install the package fuse. Depending which file system you want to use, you need additional plug-ins available as separate packages. FUSE plug-ins are not shipped with &sle;.

Generally you do not have to configure FUSE, you just use it. However, it is a good idea to create a directory where all your mountpoints are combined. For example, you can create a directory ~/mounts and insert your subdirectories for your different file systems there.

sect1.title: Mounting an NTFS Partition
sect1.para: NTFS, the New Technology File System, is the default file system of Windows. To mount a Windows partition as a normal user, proceed as follows:

step.para: Become root and install the package ntfs-3g.
Create a directory that is to be used as a mount point, e.g. ~/mounts/windows.

Find out which Windows partition you need. Use &yast; and start the partitioner module to see which partition belongs to Windows, but do not modify anything. Alternatively, become &rootuser; and execute /sbin/fdisk -l. Look for partitions with a partition type of HPFS/NTFS.
Mount the partition in read-write mode. Replace the placeholder DEVICE with your respective Windows partition:
If you want to use your Windows partition in readonly mode, append -o ro:

The command ntfs-3g uses the current user (uid) and group id (gid) to mount the given device. If you want to set the write permissions to a different user, use the command id USER to get the output of the uid and gid values. Set it with:
step.screen: id tux uid=1000(tux) gid=100(users) Gruppen=100(users),16(dialout),33(video) ntfs-3g /dev/DEVICE MOUNT POINT -o uid=1000,gid=100
step.para: Find additional options in the manpage.

sect1.para: To unmount the resource, run fusermount -u MOUNT POINT.

sect1.title: Mounting Remote File System with SSHFS
sect1.para: SSH, the secure shell network protocol, can be used to exchange data between two computers using a secure channel. To establish a SSH connection through FUSE, proceed as follows:

step.para: Create a directory that is to be used as a mount point. A good idea is to use ~/mounts/HOST. Replace HOST with the name of your remote computer.
Enter your password for the remote computer.

sect1.para: To unmount the resource, run fusermount -u MOUNT POINT.

sect1.title: Mounting an ISO File System
sect1.para: To look into an ISO image, you can mount it with the fuseiso package:

step.para: Create a directory that is to be used as a mount point, e.g. ~/mounts/iso.

sect1.para: You can only read content from the ISO image, but you can not write back. To unmount the resource, use fusermount -u MOUNT POINT.
